episode.title: Tira, Bombay Shaving Co., Inde Wild | WTF is Fueling India’s Beauty & Skincare Revolution? | Ep. 25
episode.framing: Three founders leading India’s skincare wave – Bhakti Modi (Tira), Shantanu Deshpande (Bombay Shaving Company), and Diipa Khosla (Inde Wild) join Nikhil Kamath to share the highs and lows of building beauty and skincare brands and the trends shaping this booming industry.

guests.name: Bhakti Modi
guests.bio: CEO of Tira, Reliance Retail Ventures Limited's beauty platform.

guests.name: Diipa Khosla
guests.bio: Founder of Inde Wild, a globally recognized beauty and wellness brand leveraging Ayurvedic principles.

guests.name: Shantanu Deshpande
guests.bio: Founder of Bombay Shaving Company, a men's grooming brand in India.

insights.title: Founder Stories, Valuations, and Market Dynamics
insights.content: This segment introduces the founders and their personal journeys into the beauty and personal care industry. Key discussion points include the market potential of haircare in India, the role of founder persona in brand building (especially for influencer-led brands like Inde Wild), and an analysis of valuation multiples for high-growth D2C businesses in the BPC space. Shantanu from Bombay Shaving Company discusses the challenge of building conversation around low-engagement products like razors, while Diipa highlights the 'trampoline jump' effect of having an existing community.
insights.context: The discussion covers market size definitions, personal backgrounds of Bhakti Modi and Diipa Khosla, and Shantanu Deshpande's transition from consulting to entrepreneurship.
insights.speaker: Nikhil Kamath

insights.title: Haircare Market Size in India
insights.content: The overall haircare market in India is estimated to be approximately $7-8 billion.
insights.context: Nikhil Kamath asks about the market size breakdown. The guests clarify that a significant portion of this market is still dominated by hair oil.
insights.speaker: Diipa Khosla

insights.title: Flagship Product Contribution
insights.content: Inde Wild's flagship 'Champi Hair Oil' product accounts for 50-55% of its total sales, highlighting the importance of a strong, focused launch product.
insights.context: Diipa Khosla discusses her initial strategy and the performance of her first products, noting how one product became disproportionately successful.
insights.speaker: Diipa Khosla

insights.title: D2C Valuation Multiples (Early Stage)
insights.content: Valuation multiples for D2C brands in India range from 4x to 5x revenue for companies demonstrating 40% year-on-year growth.
insights.context: The discussion on valuations for beauty and personal care brands suggests higher multiples for high-growth companies in exploding markets.
insights.speaker: Shantanu Deshpande

insights.title: Founder Persona as a Marketing Advantage
insights.content: The founder's public persona or existing community (especially in the beauty space) serves as a significant initial advantage for brand launch, providing a 'trampoline jump' for customer acquisition.
insights.context: Diipa Khosla attributes the initial success of Inde Wild partly to her 2.5 million community built through content creation. The founder's face, similar to Charlotte Tilbury, changes the marketing landscape.
insights.speaker: Diipa Khosla
insights.action_item: New founders should consider leveraging their existing personal brand or building a community before product launch to accelerate initial growth.

insights.title: Profitability as a Valuation Multiplier
insights.content: The transition from revenue-based valuation multiples (4-5x revenue) to EBITDA-based multiples (40x forward EBITDA) occurs once a D2C brand achieves profitability, leading to a significant revaluation.
insights.context: Shantanu Deshpande discusses the major inflection point in a brand's life cycle when it becomes profitable.
insights.speaker: Shantanu Deshpande
insights.action_item: Founders should understand that becoming profitable is not just about sustaining operations, but also fundamentally changes the financial model and investment appeal of the business.

insights.title: Do: Focus on a Single SKU for Launch
insights.content: For new founders, focusing very clearly on one product for launch can simplify strategy and accelerate market traction. Inde Wild, for example, built its initial success on a single product.
insights.context: Diipa Khosla focused on the Champi Hair Oil as a core product, which now represents more than half her sales. This strategy provides clear focus for a new brand.
insights.speaker: Diipa Khosla
insights.action_item: Identify your hero product early and dedicate resources to its success before diversifying your catalog.

insights.title: Don't: Underestimate the Value of 'First Mover' in Digital Channels
insights.content: When Diipa started content creation a decade ago, she knew it was the right time to capitalize on the changing media landscape as a first mover. New founders today must find new first-mover opportunities in emerging platforms and channels.
insights.context: Diipa recalls her decision to transition from law to blogging despite her family's objections, recognizing the impending shift in digital media and influencer marketing.
insights.speaker: Diipa Khosla
insights.action_item: Don't dismiss new platforms or content formats early in their life cycle, as being a first mover can provide significant long-term competitive advantages in brand building.

quotes.quote_text: We all use Tally. Yeah. It's just... it's become a household name.
quotes.author: Bhakti Modi

quotes.quote_text: I need to be the first mover here. This is going to be big.
quotes.author: Diipa Khosla

quotes.quote_text: My business has zero conversation. When was the last time you spoke about your razor to anyone?
quotes.author: Shantanu Deshpande

quotes.quote_text: The outcome, we're very much going after that we want to elicit is, somebody goes and starts a business in what we speak about.
quotes.author: Nikhil Kamath

quotes.quote_text: The moment of transition is when you become profitable. When you start going from four times revenue, five times revenue, to 40 times forward EBITDA.
quotes.author: Shantanu Deshpande
